skill.name: medchem
skill.description: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural alerts, complexity metrics, for compound prioritization and library filtering.
skill.summary: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: All 288 static findings are false positives. The static analyzer misidentified markdown code fences (backticks) as shell execution, Python file operations as Node.js fs, medicinal chemistry terminology (MD5, DES) as cryptographic weaknesses, and molecule validation as reconnaissance. This is a legitimate drug discovery library with no malicious code.

content.value_statement: Drug discovery requires filtering large compound libraries for drug-like properties. This skill applies established medicinal chemistry rules including Rule of Five, Veber, and PAINS filters to prioritize compounds and identify structural alerts efficiently.
actual_capabilities: Apply drug-likeness rules including Rule of Five, Veber, and CNS criteria
Detect structural alerts and PAINS patterns in molecules
Calculate molecular complexity metrics for synthetic accessibility
Filter compound libraries by physicochemical properties
Identify specific chemical groups like hinge binders and Michael acceptors
limitations: Does not perform molecular docking or binding affinity prediction
Does not generate or modify molecular structures
Does not access external databases or APIs
Results should be combined with domain expertise for final decisions

use_cases.title: Prioritize lead compounds
use_cases.description: Filter virtual screening hits to identify drug-like candidates for synthesis.

use_cases.title: Assess compound quality
use_cases.description: Evaluate synthesized compounds against established medicinal chemistry rules.

use_cases.title: Library design
use_cases.description: Design focused compound libraries with optimal physicochemical properties.

prompt_templates.title: Basic filtering
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter this list of SMILES using the Rule of Five and identify compounds that pass.

prompt_templates.title: Structural alerts
prompt_templates.prompt: Check these molecules for PAINS patterns and common structural alerts. Report any alerts found.

prompt_templates.title: Lead optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply lead-like criteria and Lilly demerits filter to prioritize compounds for optimization.

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply multiple filters including Rule of Five, NIBR filters, and complexity metrics to my compound library.

output_examples.input: Filter this SMILES list for drug-likeness: CC(=O)OC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)O, c1ccccc1, CCN
output: Benzene: Passes Ro5 but fails H-bond donor/acceptor requirements
Summary: 2 of 3 molecules pass drug-likeness criteria

output_examples.input: Check for PAINS patterns in these molecules
output: No PAINS patterns detected in the first molecule
Second molecule contains rhodanine substructure (PAINS alert)
Third molecule flagged for catechol pattern

best_practices: Combine multiple filter types for comprehensive assessment
Use parallel processing for large compound libraries
anti_patterns: Blindly accepting or rejecting compounds based solely on rule pass/fail
Ignoring structural alerts in favor of property-based rules alone
Applying strict filters too early in the discovery pipeline

faq.question: What is the Rule of Five?
faq.answer: Lipinski's Rule of Five predicts oral bioavailability based on MW ≤ 500, LogP ≤ 5, HBD ≤ 5, HBA ≤ 10.

faq.question: What are PAINS filters?
faq.answer: Pan Assay Interference compounds are molecules that show activity through non-specific mechanisms.

faq.question: Can I use this for covalent inhibitor design?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill can identify Michael acceptors and other reactive groups useful for covalent inhibitors.

faq.question: What file formats are supported?
faq.answer: Input formats include CSV, TSV, SDF, and plain text files with SMILES.

faq.question: Does this require RDKit?
faq.answer: Yes, medchem depends on RDKit for molecular operations. Install via pip install medchem.

faq.question: How are results structured?
faq.answer: Results include pass/fail status for each rule, detailed violation information, and demerit scores.
